characters: BOBBY AND HIS GRANDFATHER ON THE PHONE
ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE TREE
FROM THE OTHER SIDE OF THE BARN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is one of those country cemeteries that would be an ordinary pasture without the grim slabs. AUDREY, 30s, in a flowing dress that gently rolls like wa in the breeze, stands next to... CHEYENNE, 8, an adorable little likeness of her mother. Together, they’re a symbol of all that’s beautiful about life. They gaze blankly at a casket in an open grave, pondering mortality.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: We should go. She puts her hands on Cheyenne’s shoulders. Steers her to a single car parked on the gravel road.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: How come everyone left so soon?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Probably had things to do.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: There weren’t that many people.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Grandpa was pretty old.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Then it seems like he would have had more friends than anyone.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Most of his friends have already died, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is small with add-ons, isolated and derelict, w a couple of dilapidated buildings behind it, an old barn machine shed. Other than the dusty road leading to it, it surrounded by woodlands. Audrey's car pulls up the gravel driveway, stops behind t house. Audrey and Cheyenne climb out, scan the area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I ever been here before?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Yes. You were too young to remember. I usually visited while you were with grandma and grandpa. They approach the barn like they’re walking in the park.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: I thought this was my grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: No, this was my grandpa. Cheyenne drifts toward a field as Audrey reaches the door AUDREY (CONT’D) Don’t go too far, Cheyenne. And don’t get your dress dirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey steps cautiously into the dingy building. It’s fil with a lifetime’s worth of dusty old farm equipment. A CO OF ROPE hangs on the wall. Audrey touches an old harness, smacks the dust off her ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheyenne approaches a large woodpile. When she gets close a covey of quail suddenly erupts from the pile, their TWEETING filling the air. Caught off guard, Cheyenne falls back onto the ground. Sh watches in wonder as the birds fill nearby trees. Audrey steps out of the barn to see what’s going on.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: What did you do? Cheyenne climbs off the ground and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Nothing. I just walked to the woodpile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, come away from there. Don’t bother the birds. Cheyenne makes her way back.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: I didn’t. Audrey brushes Cheyenne’s dress off.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I told you not to get dirty and it’s the first thing you did.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. She points to a dusty spot on Audrey’s dress. Audrey brus it off.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I guess I should have told myself not to get dirty too. They share a laugh. Audrey puts her arm around Cheyenne. AUDREY (CONT’D) Come on. Let’s look around some more.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Are we going into the house?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I have to get the key from Mr. Pendleton. INT. BOBBY’S OFFICE - DAY 5 BOBBY, 30s, affluent and sleazy, paces behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Those water rights have been in his family since the eighteen hundreds. We now see the two men Bobby speaks to... First there’s JAWARI, late 30s, an African-American with moustache. His face has a gentle quality. Then there’s RAINY, 30s, slouched in his chair. His eyes would be completely empty except for a sinister tinge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man’s personally owned them since nineteen-thirty-nine. It’s going to take some persuasion. Bobby leans over his desk to bring full attention to what he’s about to emphasize.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want you to persuade him. Do you two know each other? Jawari and Rainy look each other over.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I’ve seen him around.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I got a friend who said he bought a skimpy bag of weed from him. Jawari stiffens, offended.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I don’t sell skimpy bags.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Had a bunch of stems in it.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Bullshit. Bobby dismisses them with a wave as he sits.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: All right, all right. Jawari, Rainy. Rainy, Jawari. Can you two work together? Rainy leans on Bobby’s desk with a smart aleck smirk.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Hey, man, I’m a professional. Bobby looks at Jawari for an answer. Jawari nods.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: All right, listen. I just want you to loosen the old man up. Do not kill him.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: When do you want it done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. Around noon. Just hold him there. I’1l drop by later with the papers.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: What if he gives us trouble? Bobby flashes Rainy a sharp look.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Listen, asshole. What did I just say? Do not kill him. He can’t sign any papers dead.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I was just asking. He might have a shotgun or something.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: He’s in his nineties. Can’t you handle a guy in his nineties? EXT. TRAILER PARK -— DAY 6 The back door of a tiny trailer opens. Audrey leans out, hanging off the doorframe.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Cheyenne! Dinner’s ready! She retreats, closing the door, almost like a cuckoo cloc INT. AUDREY’S TRAILER - LIVING ROOM - DAY 7 Audrey turns from the back door, makes her way through th modest family area and to the...

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN 8
dialogues.text: She stops over the stove where a pot of soup simmers. Gra ladle and stirs. Cheyenne rushes through the front door, breathing heavily carrying a piece of paper with tape on it.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Why are you out of breath?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James and Chris were chasing me and Lucia. They said they were going to throw us in the pond.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Oh really? Go wash up. Cheyenne starts for the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's that? Cheyenne hurries back, still hyper, holding the paper out

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: It was on the door. What’s for dinner? She hands Audrey the paper and scurries off.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Vegetable soup. Audrey examines the paper. It’s a FINAL EVICTION NOTICE. frowns, looks up. Cheyenne’s already in the bathroom with water running. Audrey calls out. AUDREY (CONT’D) What did you think of the farm? Did you like it?

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah! It was okay! Audrey pulls two bowls from the cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Just okay? Cheyenne comes back to the kitchen as Audrey fills a bowl

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: It was fun to run around. There’s lots of places to go. They sit at the table to eat. Audrey nudges a package of crackers toward Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: There's crackers if you want. Cheyenne grabs some, crushes them over her soup.  AUDREY (CONT’D) So, you know, Grandpa was kind of a hermit in his old age. I’m probably the only family he really had any contact with. She waits for a reaction. Cheyenne sips her soup. AUDREY (CONT’D) He might leave me something in his will.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Really? Like what?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Like, I don’t know. Mr. Pendleton hinted he might leave me the farm.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Really? Audrey hesitates, trying to be tactful.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: It has a lot more space than the trailer.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Do you have to work tonight? Audrey’s a little surprised by Cheyenne’s disinterest.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Who’s watching me?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Lucia’s mom. Cheyenne looks up, grinning. Audrey smiles. AUDREY (CONT’D) Don’t let the boys throw you in the pond. Cheyenne giggles.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a small all-night place. Audrey finishes scribbling an order for a TRUCK DRIVER at the counter.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Would you like more coffee?

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I‘ll put this right in. She glides to a table as TWO CUSTOMERS leave behind scatt empty dishes. AUDREY (CONT’D) Thanks, guys. She stacks dirty plates. Notices the tip. She picks up... maybe a dollar and a half in change. Total. She’s stunned 10 INT. MARTY’S OFFICE - LATER 10 MARTY, the owner, 50s, sits at his desk looking over tax papers, confused and frustrated. Audrey knocks.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Got a minute? Marty glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: A minute is about all you got. I’m stressin’ over this tax mess. This is my last extension. Audrey sits across from him.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I’m having some hard times financially. Marty gestures at the tax papers.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Aren’t we all?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I need to make some extra money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That’s what tips are for. You want more money? Flirt with the customers more.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I’m not asking for a raise. I was just wondering if I could get some extra hours.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I’m looking at cutting back hours as it is.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I got a kid, Marty.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Please don’t give me a sob story. I get at least one of those a week. Marty goes back to work, ignoring her. Defeated, Audrey starts to leave. Marty sighs, rubs his face.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right, look. You need some extra cash and I need to relax. We're a match made in heaven. He shrugs, wondering if she gets his meaning. She gets it she doesn’t appreciate it. She summons courage.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You owe me overtime pay.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (annoyed) I told you, you'll get your overtime when I get my tax refund.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I know you have the money. You just bought a new car.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: So we’ve come to this? You wanna play hard ball? Might I remind you that there’s no actual record of this alleged overtime. Audrey stares in disbelief. It quickly turns to anger.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I knew you would do this.  11 12 10.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You all agreed to it.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You changed all our time-sheets.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You signed them.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: What choice did we have?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna pay you. I just can’t do it right now. You'll just have to wait... like we agreed. She turns away, speaking under her breath.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Asshole.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I heard that. That’s a code of conduct violation. I could dock your pay for that. She walks away while he’s talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jawari parks his car a few spaces over from Rainy’s truck Rainy climbs out, clumsily carrying a rifle and a handgun all while holding onto a plastic ring for a sixpack of be INT. JAWARI’S CAR - DAY 12 Jawari watches stunned as Rainy awkwardly climbs into his car. Once settled, Rainy holds up the sixpack.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Wanna beer?

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: What the fuck is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: What? It’s just beer.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I’m talking about you carrying guns right out in the open.  11.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Nobody saw me. (re: the rifle) Besides, this isn’t a gun. It’s a rifle.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: You really think we need an assault rifle for an old man?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Here’s your weapon. He gives Jawari the handgun.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: A six shooter?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: It's a thirty-eight. That’s respectable.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: How come I get a six shooter like I’m a fuckin’ cowboy and you get a semi automatic rifle?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Man, ‘cause that’s what I got. That was my daddy’s gun.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Daddy? You call your old man daddy?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: What is your problem? I just thought we’d have a beer together. Jawari glances at the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Where’s the bullets? Rainy digs them out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I got your bullets right here, man. He pulls out six bullets, hands them to Jawari.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Six bullets? That’s all I get?  13 12.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: How many do you need? It’s a six shooter. Besides, we’re not supposed to kill anyone, remember? Jawari stuffs the bullets in his jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got any weed? Jawari gives Rainy an annoyed look.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: It’s all stems, man.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, man. You know I was just messin’ with you about that. Besides, I know your personal stash will be the good shit. Jawari hesitates, then pulls a fat bag from his pocket. R grins from ear to ear.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's what I’m talkin’ about. INT. MR. PENDLETON’S OFFICE - DAY 13 MR. PENDLETON, 80s, a relaxed folksy lawyer, removes a ke from a drawer. He steps around his desk to meet Audrey an Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: This is Mr. Pendleton. He’s handling Grandpa's estate. Mr. Pendleton smiles at Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: My, I never knew he had such a pretty great granddaughter. Cheyenne smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: My great grandpa had an estate?

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: Yes, he owned eighty acres. Cheyenne has no idea how much that is, but it sounds impressive.  13.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Wow, that’s a lot.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: Yes, it is. He looks up at Audrey as he hands her the key. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) Do you have any plans for it if he leaves it to you? Audrey stares at the key, cautious about her words.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: It needs a lot of work. I probably couldn’t sell it for much. I’ve been wondering if it wouldn’t be cheaper to live there. Cheyenne looks up. This is news to her.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: Well, the will won't be officially executed until next week. We'll go over the specifics then. Audrey glances down at Cheyenne, smiles awkwardly. Mr. Pendleton picks up on her distress. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) I was at the funeral. I don’t know if you saw me.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks. And thanks for the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: You know, I worked with your grandfather on my very first job. We were just boys.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I didn’t know that. Mr. Pendleton smiles at the thought.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: Picking the best corn we ever ate. Audrey smiles. Mr. Pendleton turns to Cheyenne.  14. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) The first time I saw your mother, she was younger than you are now.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: And do you know, she ran away from me? Cheyenne giggles. Audrey tries to recall.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: I stopped by for a visit one day. They said you took time to warm up to people. After about ten minutes, I caught you spying on me from the corner of the house. Another ten minutes and you were offering me a cup of pretend tea. Audrey and Cheyenne laugh. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) By the time I left, you were hanging onto my neck. They had to pull you off me.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: So I warmed up to you finally?

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. You were a clever one too. You used a coffee can lid for a Frisbee and got it stuck on the roof. You tied a rope to a baseball mitt and threw it up there.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Now that sounds like me.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Did she get it down?

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: She sure did. As the laughter subsides, Mr. Pendleton gives Audrey a sympathetic look.  15. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) An answer has no purpose without a problem, you know. Audrey stares at him, perceiving he’s referring to her current situation now.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: But is there always an answer?

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: Oh, I think a clever girl will find one. Sometimes you just need to repurpose a few things.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: And if that doesn’t work?

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: Leave it to the wind. It’1l eventually blow off whatever’s on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I’m the one who runs away, though, remember?

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: But you come back. His words lift Audrey's spirits a little. She glances at key and returns a fragile smile.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Thanks. 14 INT. BOBBY’S GRANDFATHER'S BEDROOM - DAY 14 Bobby helps his GRANDFATHER out of a wheelchair and into

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I’m going to meet with the old man this afternoon. His grandfather strains to climb into bed. He coughs, sic He’s on his deathbed.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I quit worrying about that old man thirty years ago. We hated each other but we respected each other.  15 16. He nestles into a comfortable position. Bobby sits at his side.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: But you could never get him to sell. Even Dad couldn’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to end up like your father.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I won’t. I’m gonna show you I can run the business. His grandfather puts his hand on Bobby’s. Reminisces.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do, Bobby? In my day, when you didn’t like someone, you told him to his face, right before you loosened his jaw for him. If he had any guts, he cracked a chair over your head. He coughs. Bobby watches, knowing he’s the last remnant o his family with his grandfather so close to perishing. GRANDFATHER (CONT’D) The old days are gone. Washed away like a creek bed. You can’t just muscle your way around anymore. No one respects guts anymore. He closes his eyes, drifts off. Bobby clutches his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna make you proud of me. His grandfather grumbles under his breath.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Thanks for helping me off the shitter. INT. JAWARI’S CAR - MOVING - DAY 15 Rainy finishes off a beer.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: We need some more beer. You got any money?  16 17.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I will after we get this job done.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: We need some money now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jawari’s car pulls to a stop at a red light. Rainy’s elbo hangs out the open window. He looks over at the driver of car in the next lane. It's a pretty blonde woman, 20s. NOTTA CHANCE. Her window partially up and there’s a splotch of birdshit on it.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: What’s your name, darlin’? She gives Rainy a cold sneer.

dialogues.speaker: NOTTA
dialogues.text: Notta.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Notta. Is that Mexican?

dialogues.speaker: NOTTA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Notta what?

dialogues.speaker: NOTTA
dialogues.text: Notta chance. Jawari bursts out laughing. Rainy glances at him, turns playfully back to Notta.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You got birdshit on your window.

dialogues.speaker: NOTTA
dialogues.text: Why don’t you lick it off? Rainy hangs out the window.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You think I won’t? A sly grin sneaks onto Notta’s face. She’s game.  18.

dialogues.speaker: NOTTA
dialogues.text: I’‘1l give you ten dollars if you lick that birdshit off. Rainy climbs out. The light turns green.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Hey, come on, man. The light turned green. Rainy steps toward Notta’s car.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Bitch, do you even have ten dollars? He gets close enough to see down into Notta’s car. She pu a ten dollar bill from her wallet. Rainy sees she has a l more money. She waves the ten.

dialogues.speaker: NOTTA
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you'll do it. He looks into her eyes with a smart aleck smirk as he sti his tongue out and... licks that birdshit off her window it’s chocolate and whipped cream. Notta’s mouth falls open.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Mmmmmmmmmmn. Now gimme my money. Notta, still shocked, holds out the ten. Rainy grabs it w one hand and with the other... slings open a balisong (a. a butterfly knife), presses the blade against Notta’s thr

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ll take the rest of it too. Jawari sees what’s going on from his car. Scans, panicked

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: What are you doing, man? Let’s get out of here. Notta holds up the wallet. Rainy grabs it, backs away.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Remember, I got your address. If you call the police, you better hope they find me before I find you. As he climbs into Jawari’s car, Notta can’t help but ask.  17 19.

dialogues.speaker: NOTTA
dialogues.text: If you were going to rob me, why did you lick the birdshit off my window? Rainy hangs out the window as Jawari pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: That's just somethin’ for you to remember me by, darlin’. He laughs like a crazy man as they drive off. INT. AUDREY’S CAR - MOVING - DAY 17 Audrey bickers with an upset Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I didn’t say anything before. It’s not set in stone.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: What about school? Will I still go to the same school?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: What about all my friends?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Honey, I don’t know what’s going to happen. All I know is we can’t afford the rent anymore.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: What about dad? Can we ask him to help us?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Your dad doesn’t give us any money. Cheyenne’s eyes well with tears.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: But if he knew we might lose our home, then he might.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: All he'd do is try and take you away from me. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that what you want? To live with your dad? You’d still have to change schools. It gets really quiet for several moments. Both Audrey and Cheyenne gaze ahead, pondering. Then...

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: I know the birthday cards from dad are really from you. Audrey glances between Cheyenne and the road, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: No postage stamps or return address. So you can’t threaten me with living with dad. I already know he wouldn’t take me. Audrey smiles, bittersweet, at Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You’re pretty smart, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Yes. Just don’t put a bumper sticker on the car about it. They share a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jawari’s car pulls up the driveway, parks behind the hous 19 INT. JAWARI’S CAR - DAY 19 Jawari and Rainy scan the area.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: This place is a piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Yeah, but there’s supposedly a lot of water around here.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Seems weird Bobby would go through all this trouble for some water.  21.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: He’s just trying to impress his grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jawari and Rainy get out. Jawari puts his gun in his jack Rainy hangs his rifle over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: You have to carry that out in the open?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I‘1l stick it down in my pants. (grabs his crotch) Nobody will see it next to my dick. Jawari rolls his eyes. They walk toward the back door.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where’s yours?

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: If it was up your ass, I bet you’d know where it was.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Damn, brother, what spoiled your taco?

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: (defensive) Taco? What do you mean by taco?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Ain’t that what they eat down there in Dominica or wherever?

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Fuck you, man. They arrive at the door. Jawari knocks. They wait idly.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: So how long did it take you to smear that doo-doo across your lip? Jawari rubs his moustache, self-satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Shit, I shave twice a day.  22. Rainy bangs on the door.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Open up, old man! We know you’re in there! (re: Jawari’s moustache) If you shave twice a day, I shit gold bricks. You could hardly tickle a twat with that Velcro looking thing.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: You can kiss my damn ass, cowboy. I get more pussy than you can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Well, if we’re counting imaginary pussy, then I guess you’re gonna win. Rainy bangs on the door again.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re not fooling anyone! We know you’re in there! A few more moments go by.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t think he’s in there. Jawari turns and scans the grounds.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: He must be around here somewhere. The two men spread out as they approach the barn.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You check the woods on that side and come up behind the barn. I’11 check the other side and come up by that woodpile. Rainy stops near a tree while Jawari is still close by.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I hate trees.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: How can you hate trees? No one hates trees.  21 22 23.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I do. Once when I was hiding out from the police, I was stuck in the woods for weeks. Nothin’ but goddamn trees everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: No one hates trees, man. It’s impossible.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Fuck trees. Rainy looks up the tall tree with contempt.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Know what I’m gonna do? I’m gonna piss on this goddamn tree. Rainy unzips his pants, and true to his word, starts peei on the tree. He flips the tree off.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck you, tree. Jawari shakes his head and moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey’s car crunches gravel along the road toward the fa stirring up dust and pinging rocks off the fender wells. INT. AUDREY’S CAR - DAY 22 Dust floats past the windows.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I’‘1l never get used to all this dust. I hope the gravel doesn’t tear the car up. They pull up next to a large mailbox. Audrey lowers the window, opens the box. It’s filled with letters and newspapers. Audrey takes them in. AUDREY (CONT’D) We've got to cancel Grandpa’s paper.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: The mailbox is so big.  23 24 25 24.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: We could live in the mailbox if the house doesn’t work out. They giggle as Audrey raises the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey's car pulls up the driveway and parks behind Jawar INT. AUDREY’S CAR - DAY 24 Audrey studies Jawari'’s car, confused.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Whose car is that, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey and Cheyenne get out of the car. Audrey pulls out key as she walks toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s someone from the lumber company. I think Grandpa was going to thin the forest. Cheyenne separates, toward an apple tree in the back yard AUDREY (CONT’D) Don’t you want to see inside?

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: I just want to see the apples. Audrey arrives at the door, unlocks it.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Okay, but don’t eat any apples until you let me check them out first. Then... the massive TWEETING of a large covey of quail gr Audrey’s attention. She turns to see the birds filling th trees. She steps away from the house, calls out.  26 25. AUDREY (CONT’D) Cheyenne, I told you not to bother the birds!

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m right here, Mom. Audrey looks toward a bush near the apple tree. There’s Cheyenne, looking right at her. Audrey isn’t sure what to think. She looks toward the woodpile with an uneasy feeling.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Wait here. Audrey cautiously approaches the woodpile, scanning.

dialogues.speaker: FROM THE OTHER SIDE OF THE BARN
dialogues.text: Rainy hides in the back. Jawari is crouched behind the woodpile. Rainy peeks around the corner and pulls back. Jawari peeks through an opening in the woodpile. Audrey stoops a little as she steps nearer. She searches woodpile until she lays her eyes... Directly on Jawari’s. Audrey’s eyes widen in terror. Jawari stands. Audrey turns and runs, screaming... AUDREY (CONT’D) Cheyenne, get in the car! Get in the car and lock the door! Cheyenne sees Jawari chasing her mother. She reacts quick Climbs into the car and locks the door. INT. AUDREY’S CAR - DAY 26 Cheyenne clambers to the driver’s side and opens the door She locks it again, then pushes it wide open. She barely makes it back over before Audrey scrambles in. Audrey slams the door just as Jawari reaches for the latc

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: (outside) Open the door! Open the door! Audrey fumbles for her keys in a panic. Drops them in the passenger floorboard. Cheyenne grabs them, finds the key.  27 26.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Here it is! Jawari bangs on the window as Audrey gropes the ignition. Manages to get the key in and start the car.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Open up! We’re not gonna hurt you! Audrey backs up with Jawari following, banging on the roo

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’re not gonna hurt you! Audrey works the shifter into drive. As she starts to pul forward... Rainy appears at the passenger side window with the rifle aimed directly at Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Stop the car or I'll kill the kid. Audrey freezes instantly, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put the car into park. Audrey hesitates. Not defiantly but paralyzed with fear. Rainy aims upward. BANG! Fires off a round, then aims at Cheyenne again.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was a fucking warning shot. Put the car into park or I'll shoot her. Audrey struggles to get her bearings. Puts the shifter in park. Rainy keeps his rifle trained on Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Unlock the door. Audrey fights to focus, then unlocks her door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jawari opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Get out.  28 27. He takes her by the arm as she climbs out. Looks at Rainy

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are we gonna do with them? Rainy lowers his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You see any rope around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rustic charm, fallen into disarray. Dusty unkempt furnitu deteriorated over years of wear and neglect. Audrey and Cheyenne, both with their hands bound behind t are marshalled into the kitchen and family room area. It’ small the kitchen table is adjacent to the couch. Rainy pushes Audrey onto the couch. Cheyenne sits beside Rainy tosses the extra rope onto the table. Kneels in fro of Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Let’s start with names. I know you’re Cheyenne. That’s a pretty name. Is it because you’re shy? Cheyenne shakes her head. Rainy’s attention turns to Audr

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s your name? Audrey is so scared, her mouth is dry when she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Audrey.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Audrey? That’s not that pretty. What’s your middle name?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Michelle.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Michelle. That’s much better. He looks up playfully at Jawari.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sings Beatles’ song) Michelle. Ma belle.  28. He laughs. Jawari keeps a stony face.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Hey, man, can I talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: In a minute. (to Audrey) Where’s the old man? Audrey absorbs a moment, confused as to what they want.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Grandpa?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Yeah, Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: He died. Jawari steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Died? Who owns the water rights?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Water rights? I don’t know. Whoever he left them to, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: When will we find out who gets ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: The will gets read next week. Rainy stands.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: We can’t watch them for a whole week. Jawari steps toward the next room.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Let’s talk. They go into the...  29 29. LIVING ROOM —- DAY 29 It's as large as the other two rooms put together, with a large open space in the middle of the floor. Jawari faces Rainy so they can talk privately.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Okay, first off, I don’t like you pointing a rifle at a kid.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Really? The old man was once a kid. Audrey was once a kid. If someone’s seventeen and turns eighteen tomorrow, do I have to wait until tomorrow for it to be okay to point a rifle at them?

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I’ve had it with your smartass bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I’ve had it with your pussyfooting.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Hey, fuck you, cowboy.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Zulu.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Hey, I was born in America, dumb shit. And do you even know what a Zulu is?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Yeah, he’s the guy who spends all day playing with chicken bones ‘cause he’s got the best drugs.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: That’s a sangoma, dumbass.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: It’s all ooga booga shit to me, buddy. They stare holes into each other another moment, then loo toward the next room.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are we gonna do with them?  30.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY ROOM/KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Jawari and Rainy return.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: (to Audrey) If you'll sign the water rights over, we'll let you go.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: We don’t even know if she'll get them. Jawari keeps his gaze fixed on Audrey.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: If she does, then we’ll already have the contract. How about it? Audrey stares, confused a moment, then gently nods.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Bobby will be by in a bit with the papers. You sign and that’s it. Rainy kneels in front of Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: What about you, shy one? You know anything about this? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Audrey) Does she talk?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: She’s scared.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: (to Cheyenne) You mad at me because I pointed a rifle at you? Cheyenne nods.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, if you don’t talk, I’m gonna aim it at you again. And this time, I might fire it.  31.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Damn it, Rainy, I told you not to threaten the kid with a rifle.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You said you didn’t want me to point it at her. Did I point it at her? (to Cheyenne) Go on, shy one. Cheyenne looks to her mother for approval.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Go ahead and answer him, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Mom and me can’t afford rent so we thought we might move in here.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Well, now, that’s interesting. How do you know you’ll get the house?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: We don’t.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Was I talking to you? Let her answer.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Mr. Pendleton said we’1ll probably get it because Grandpa was a hermit and didn’t have much family left. Jawari reaches into his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: So that’s it then. She’1ll probably get the water rights too. Problem solved. He pulls out his gun. Sets it on the table as he sits.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All we have to do is wait for Bobby. Rainy swaggers to the refrigerator. Noses around inside.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I need a fucking beer.  32. He goes through the cupboards.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Damn. What did the old man eat? Chipped paint? There’s more mouse shit than food in these cupboards.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: He was ninety. Maybe mouse shit was his secret to longevity. Why don’t you eat some, cowboy?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You think I won’t? How much?

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I told you, I don’t have any money. You got some beer in the car, remember?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s right. Why don’t you go get it for me?

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Rainy playfully checks out Audrey.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Audrey, go get my beer.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Untie me. Rainy chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: She’s got wit. I like that. Rainy eyes Audrey as he sits next to Jawari.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, man, step out for a spell. Jawari looks at Rainy. Glances at Audrey.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: We didn’t come here for that.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I know, but, you know... Speaks quietly. Jawari gives Rainy a look that says he’s not playing arou  31 33.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Leave her alone. Rainy smirks, not intimidated, but provocative.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You draw the line at pushing around old men, huh?

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Just leave her alone. Rainy stands, slings his rifle over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You must be the life of the party, Zulu. He saunters to the door. Winks at Audrey right before he walks out. She cringes. Jawari digs the bullets out of his jacket, puts them down the table. Picks up the gun and opens the revolver. He picks up one bullet, pauses before shoving it in the chamber. He looks at Audrey. She’s frightened. He looks at Cheyenn Same frightened face.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. It’s for him, not you. Just in case. He continues loading the gun.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Please don’t let him hurt us. Jawari pauses again, looks at Audrey. Softly nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rainy ambles to the car. Notices the tree he peed on earl as he passes by. Smirks, flips it off.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Fuck you. He leans in the car, rummages around, pulls away with a sixpack. Pulls one free and sets the rest on the roof.  32 34. PSSSHHHT. Pops the can open. Takes a big long guzzle. Let out a loud obnoxious sigh. He wanders down the driveway, notices the woodpile. Picks rock off the driveway and throws it... POP! The rock bounces off a log. TWEETING erupts as quail rush for the trees.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Loud ass birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jawari finishes rolling a joint. Lights it and takes a pu Rainy enters with three beers left hanging off the ring.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me you were firing one up?

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: You didn’t ask. Rainy sets his beer on the table, reaches for the joint.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Let me have some of that. Jawari hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Here. Maybe it’1l mellow you out. Rainy takes a big draw. Blows out a fog of smoke, coughin

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: (while coughing) Goddamn, this shit could bore a hole through a bank vault. Jawari laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Nah, man, it’s an acquired taste. Rainy holds it out to Audrey.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You want some?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: No, thank you.  35.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You sure? It’ll loosen you up. Get the tension out. And believe me, darlin’, I can see you’re under a lot of pressure right now. Audrey just shakes her head. Rainy holds it out to Cheyen

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What about you?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: She doesn’t want any.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I didn’t ask you. Cheyenne glances at her mother, then shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, suit yourself. Rainy takes another big draw.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: You know what you are, cowboy? You're a glutton. You don’t know when to quit. Rainy coughs a cloud of smoke, hands the joint to Jawari.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: If you want it back, you could just ask. You don’t have to get personal. Jawari laughs, taking the joint. Rainy stares at Audrey w that sinister tinge blooming in his eyes again. He squeez between her and Cheyenne. Jawari notices, keeps an eye as he takes a draw. Rainy lo Audrey up and down.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Comfortable?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: No. Would you be, tied up with two psychos in your house?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: It’s not your house yet, remember? Besides, Jawari isn’t a psycho.  36. He laughs. Jawari laughs along with him.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The worst thing Jawari has ever done is sell skimpy bags of dope.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Hey, I told you, man. I don’t sell skimpy bags.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Well, now, my friend wouldn’t lie.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Your friend is a lying sack of shit.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Now, take it easy. There’s nothin’ wrong with turning a profit. He looks down at Audrey’s lap.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Getting a little extra out of a deal... He puts his hand on her leg.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is there? He eases up her leg. Audrey, horrified, looks at Jawari.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Hey, man, come on. Rainy pauses, looks at Jawari.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You know something, Jawari? I’m getting awful tired of your blocking. What are you, Zorro?

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Man, all we got to do is wait for Bobby. You wanna fuck something that simple up? Rainy contemplates, then leaps off the couch. Walks aroun the other side of Jawari.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You’re a real killjoy, you know it?  37.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Just chill, man. Jawari takes a draw with his back to Rainy. Rainy raises rifle, pointed toward the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you take a nap? BAM! He brings the rifle butt down on the back of Jawari’ head. Audrey screams. Jawari slumps forward, falls from t chair into a heap on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Damn, that guy was annoying. He’1l be pissed when he wakes up. He steps toward Audrey. She draws back, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Please don’t hurt us. He sits between her and Cheyenne again.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Don’t fret, darlin’. I wouldn’t dream of forcing myself on you. You know what I want? I want you to ask for it. Go on. Ask for it. Audrey is so nervous, she can hardly speak.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I -- I don’t know what you want me to say.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I want you to ask... for... it.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You can. And you will.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Cheyenne. Can she leave...

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: No, fuck that. You can say it with Cheyenne here. She’s too young to understand anyway.  38.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I can't. Rainy stares at her long and hard.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Okay, then. He turns a chair facing the doorway to the next room. Pul Audrey off the couch and sits her in the chair. Grabs som rope and ties her ankles to the chair legs.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then you can sit here and see what happens next.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Please. I don’t know what you want me to say. Rainy grabs Cheyenne by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Maybe Cheyenne will ask for it. He pulls Cheyenne off the couch. She breaks into tears, scared to death, even though she doesn’t understand what’ happening. Audrey is horrified.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: No, please, just tell me what you want me to say. Rainy pulls Cheyenne along, toward the next room.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Come on, Cheyenne, let’s leave Audrey to think about things.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Please, I’ll say whatever you want. Rainy forces Cheyenne into the next room, out of sight, leaving Audrey not knowing what’s happening. Audrey screa with tears streaming down her cheeks. AUDREY (CONT’D) Take me! Take me! Her pleas are met with eerie silence. AUDREY (CONT’D) Take me! Take me! Take me!  33 39. The silence is terrifying. Audrey can hardly speak from crying. She makes one last desperate call. AUDREY (CONT’D) Take me! She finally breaks down, sobbing uncontrollably. Rainy pe back in the doorway, holding his hand over Cheyenne’s mou

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Well, if you’re gonna beg... He pushes Cheyenne down on the couch. Loosens the binds around Audrey’s ankles.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I knew my charm would wear you down . Audrey's eyes meet Cheyenne’s. The girl is traumatized.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Sweetie, I need you to be strong for mama, okay? It’s going to be all right. Then... KNOCK, KNOCK, KNOCK, at the front door. Rainy shu Audrey. He peeks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I think it’s one of those door to door proselytizers. He waits. There’s the sound of a pamphlet being left in t door. Rainy shakes his head, steps to the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man, DAVID, 30s, is walking away carrying a Bible whe Rainy opens the door. The pamphlet flutters to the porch.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: What's this? (picks it up) Why, it’s a pamphlet. Whatever could it be about? A smile fills David’s tender face as he returns. He’s innocent.  40.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hi. My name is David. I just wanted to drop by to see if you’ve heard the good news concerning our lord and savior Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Do you know what country you're in? David’s smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: It's a simple question, David. Do you know... what country... that you are in? David digests, unsettled by the awkwardness.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: America.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: That's right. This is America.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I don’t know what you’re getting at. Rainy points down the road.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Did you see that church on the corner down there?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes, the big one? It’s nice.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Well, it’s one of about a million on damn near every corner in the country. Do you really think you’re gonna run into someone who’s never heard of Jesus fuckin’ Christ. David just stares speechless.  4l.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1l tell you where you need to go. You need to go to one of those remote areas of Africa, with all those crazy tribes that worship tigers and shit. That’s where you'll find people who’ve never heard of Jesus. David shakes his head, trying to focus.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Okay. I’m sorry to bother you.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Wanna know why Christians don’t go to places like that to proselytize? Because you'll get a spear in your ass, that’s why. They’1ll make a necklace out of your fucking head.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’1l move on. He starts to turn and sees... Audrey in the window, horror all over her face. She mouth “Help me.” David turns away.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have a good day, sir. Rainy glances toward the window, suspicious. Audrey’s gon He leans back in the doorway. Looks at David walking away

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You saw something, didn’t you? David turns around.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Don’t act stupid. You saw something, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re talking about. I’11l move on. He turns away. Rainy grabs his rifle, walks out, pursuing  34 35 42.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: That’s why I hate you people. You'll lie like the devil the second it suits you. David turns, sees the rifle. Runs away. Rainy chases.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, now you’re gonna run away like a little pussy. Rainy gets close enough, RAPS David on the head. David hi the ground, senses reeling.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hate liars, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rainy shoves David, hands bound behind him, to the floor. This is the living room with the large open space.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I’m not trying to be an asshole. I just want you to admit you lied. He walks into the next room, still talking. David listens frightened, unsure what’s going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Audrey here did something to tip you off. We hear Audrey moan as Rainy grabs her. FOOTSTEPS approac

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Then you acted like you were leaving when you were really going for help. Rainy tugs Audrey into the room, shoves her to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then I asked you if you saw something and you lied.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY ROOM/KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Cheyenne toils with her binds. She glances cautiously bet Jawari unconscious on the floor and the doorway to the ne room.  43.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: David looks up at Rainy with a tight face.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Look. I don’t know what’s going on. I don’t know why you didn’t just not answer the door.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: This isn’t about me not answering the door. This is about you lying and not being able to admit it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Okay, I lied. Rainy kneels by David.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Well, now, that’s not a sincere admission, now is it, David?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you want me to say.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Yeah, there’s a lot of that going around. He stands, grabs the strap to his rifle to hold it secure

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just want you... He kicks David in the stomach. David draws in, groaning.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: +.. to admit... Rainy kicks him again. And again. And again. While Audrey screams for him to stop.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ++. you lied. Now is that... Stop it! Leave him alone! so hard? Just... admit... Please! Stop it! you lied. Rainy finally stops, breathing heavily. Gazes down at Dav  37 38

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just want a little sincerity, David. Is that too much to ask?

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY ROOM/KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Cheyenne works to free herself. She’s halfway there. She focuses on the gun. Resting on the table. Then... Jawari groans. Cheyenne quickly hides her hands behind he

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: David looks up with watery eyes, completely sincere.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I wasn’t sure what I saw. I thought I kind of knew. But I wasn’t sure. I didn't know what I was going to do. He looks at Audrey, face filled with regret.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I don’t know if I would have helped you. I wasn’t sure what I saw. I probably wouldn’t have gotten involved.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Did you hear that, Audrey? Mr. Christian was just going to leave you here to rot. It’s okay, sweetheart. You still have me. Rainy pulls David up to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I bet you wish that prayer bullshit really worked right about now, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, cowboy! Rainy whirls to see Jawari pointing the gun.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I ought to blow your head off. Rainy steps back.  39 45.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Come on, Zulu. You’re not mad at me over that little bump on the head, are you? I was just trying to get a little time alone with my lady. Jawari steps closer, still aiming the gun. Notices David.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Who the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: That's my new friend, David. He likes to preach the gospel when he isn’t leaving women and children behind to save himself.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I owe you a whack. BAM! Jawari cracks Rainy on the head with the handle of h gun. Rainy drops to the floor like a sack of flour. Jawar feels his head, grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hope his head hurts as much as mine when he wakes up. He turns toward Audrey and David.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: David knocked and he answered. Jawari shakes his head, tries to think.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: All right. Let’s all go in the other room. We’re gonna wait for Bobby. INT. BOBBY’S OFFICE - DAY 39 Bobby stuffs papers in his satchel. His grandfather steps into the room. Bobby pauses when he sees him.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What are you doing out of bed? Where’s your wheelchair?  46.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Needed to walk a bit. Get the blood going. Bobby goes back to filling his satchel. GRANDFATHER (CONT’D) Off on business?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got somethin’ I gotta take care of.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Busy man. He makes his way to a chair, eases into it. GRANDFATHER (CONT’D) When I was young, when I built all this, I was a busy man. I had nothing, and I wanted everything.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. You told me.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: My father told me, "If you wanna make a million dollars, you’re gonna have to do a million dollars worth of work."

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. You put it in a frame and hung it in your office.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Everybody thinks getting rich is getting lucky. They think of winning the lottery, or hitting the jackpot, or picking the right stocks. They don’t think about the hard work. The sacrifice. They didn’t see me digging wells, shoveling mud so thick I couldn't lift my boots out of it. Bobby opens a desk drawer. Inside is a PISTOL. He glances his grandfather to make sure he can’t see, then sneaks it into his satchel.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: They know who you are once you got money, though, don’t they?  40 His grandfather nods, preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I worked so hard to make sure my children wouldn’t have to. Now I wonder if I did the right thing. 47. Bobby stops in the middle of closing his satchel.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Why would you say that? We’ve got money, don’t we? That’s power. Nobody pushes us around.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I remember the thirst, Bobby. The parched mouth and the blistered lips. It was all about the land and the pipes in those days. They worked us like a chain gang. Somebody else decided when you got a break. When you got a drink. I said to myself, one day I’m gonna have all the water. I’m gonna dig in this dirt until the land bleeds. No one is ever gonna tell me when I can drink again. Bobby rounds the desk to help his grandfather up.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Come on. Let’s get you back to bed. His grandfather ignores him, lost in nostalgia.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: A man should have a right to drink water whenever he wants.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I agree, but I gotta go. Bobby's grandfather stands to go with him.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I remember the Bendix washing machine. INT. BOBBY’S GRANDFATHER'S BEDROOM - MOMENTS Bobby helps his grandfather walk to the bed. on about the past.

dialogues.speaker: LATER 40
dialogues.text: He’s still going

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get old, things change. You can’t stop it.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I know. Bobby helps him sit on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Your grandmother was right, you know?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: About the vacation. She wanted us all to go to the World’s Fair. Expo fifty-eight. In Brussels. Your father was just a boy. Your grandmother said we needed to spend time together as a family. I yelled at her and gave her this spiel about providing a better life for us. Bobby helps him lie back. GRANDFATHER (CONT’D) Now look at everything. My son went to prison because he wanted money the easy way. He didn’t want to earn it. And water? You just turn on the faucet. Nobody thinks twice about it. Your grandmother is gone, God rest her soul, and there’1l never be another like her. And me? I’m lying here taking my last breaths, wishing I’d gone to Belgium when I had the chance. Bobby pulls the blanket up for him. GRANDFATHER (CONT’D) They say nobody dies wishing they’d worked more. But they don’t tell you what you do wish for. All the little things that meant nothing before become so important. Bobby frowns, impatient and disinterested. 48.  41 49.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I really gotta go, okay? He moves toward the door, leaving his grandfather staring wistfully at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: That's life, Bobby. Nothing becomes everything and everything becomes nothing. INT. FARMHOUSE FAMILY ROOM/KITCHEN - DAY 4l Audrey and Cheyenne are on the couch. David sits in a recliner next to it. Jawari is at the table with his gun top.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: This was just supposed to be a simple job. All we had to do was get the old man to sign the papers. Now here we are with three hostages. The old man is dead. Jawari pauses, thinking. Audrey breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: If I sign the papers whenever this Bobby gets here, will you let us all go?

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: That’s the plan. You can’t tell anyone.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: We won’t say anything. I don’t even want the water rights. You could have just asked me for them. I can’t take care of all the pipes and filters anyway. Jawari gazes at her a moment, then laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: We could have just asked for them. He laughs harder. As it dissipates, Audrey takes a chance

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: So how did you get mixed up in all this? You seem nice.  50. Jawari stops laughing, looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Lady, don’t get the wrong idea. I’m not that nice. Audrey hesitates, still trying to gauge Jawari.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: What is this? You trying to use psychology or something?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I’m just thankful for what you did.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Really? ‘Cause it sounds like you're trying to get to know me. Like maybe you think if I get to know you, I’ll be more reluctant to hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: It’s not like that.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: You watch too much TV, Audrey. Audrey decides it’s best to just stay silent. Jawari rise

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to go to the bathroom. You think you can stay here without supervision while I do that? Audrey nods. Jawari steps to the door.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can hear what’s going on out here. He steps into the next room. Audrey, Cheyenne and David exchange nervous glances. Audrey quietly rises, motions Cheyenne and David to come her. David balks. Audrey and Cheyenne sneak to the front door. Audrey stops, notices David has stayed behind. Their eyes meet. David shakes his head, trying to discour them. Audrey struggles to get her bound hands high enough unlock the bolt.  42 43 51. CLACK. It’s not that loud, but in this quiet room, and un the circumstances, it may as well be pots and pans clangi Audrey manages to turn the doorknob. CREAK. The door opening is like tires squealing in the silence. Audrey opens slowly to mitigate the noise. Finally, it’s open enough. Audrey backs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as Audrey turns to run, she bumps right into... Jawari. She gasps.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I knew I couldn’t trust you, Audrey. He ushers them back into the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey and Cheyenne step back into the room.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Can you blame us? Jawari gestures for them to sit.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: No, but it means I can’t leave you alone for a second. Audrey and Cheyenne sit back on the couch. Jawari sits at table, rubs his face, disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Damn, Audrey. I really do have to shit, too.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I promise I won’t do it again.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: You think I’m gonna trust you now?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: There’s no way I can know whether or not it’s a trick.  44 45 52.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I know I can trust preacher. Damn, preacher, I can’t believe you didn’t even try to escape.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m trying to keep us alive.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Looked more like you were trying to keep yourself alive.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Rainy rouses. Feels his head. Winces. Struggles to get hi bearings. Looks over and sees the rifle next to him.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY ROOM/KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Rainy appears in the doorway, rifle trained on Jawari.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Zulu? Jawari looks up, not the slightest bit scared.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Put the gun down. You’re not going to shoot anyone.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: First off, I told you, it’s a goddamn rifle. He lowers the rifle, focused on a rant now.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A rifle! Don’t you know the fuckin’ difference! He holds the rifle up by the barrel.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A rifle has a goddamn rifled bore! It causes the bullet to come out spinning! Like a football! A gun has a smooth bore so its accuracy is shit! He aims the rifle at Jawari.  53.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Secondly, I thought you knew me better. What makes you think I won’t shoot your ass dead? Jawari picks the MAGAZINE for the rifle off the table, ho it up for Rainy to see.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I took the bullets out. You’d think a gun expert such as yourself would have noticed his magazine was missing. Rainy spins his rifle over, sees the empty slot.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: You’re done playing cowboy. From here on, we just wait for Bobby. Rainy stares a moment, then lowers the rifle, completely changing his tune. Ambles toward Jawari.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Ah shit, I was just messin’ with you. I wasn’t gonna shoot you. Jawari grabs his gun, points it at Rainy.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Just have a seat. We wait for Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Can’t I even sit at the table?

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: That’s too close.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Fine. I’1l sit on the couch with Audrey.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: No. (to David) You sit on the couch. (to Rainy) You take the recliner.  54. David switches to the couch. Cheyenne scoots over to be i the middle. Rainy saunters to the recliner.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Fine. I wanted the recliner anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I can’t believe the mess you've made. Rainy plants himself in the recliner.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Me? I was just having a little fun. Like the old days. Rape, pillage, burn and all that. Rainy glances at the small wood-burning stove next to him There are several thin logs on top and a couple of larger ones at the base. Rainy pulls out his balisong.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I whittle while we wait? He grabs a thin log. Slings the knife open by spinning it gracefully around his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I thought you hated trees.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I do. That’s why I don’t mind cutting them up. Jawari sighs. Rainy idly whittles.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’‘ll carve you a little tiki statue. Jawari rolls his eyes. A few moments of silence go by.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, Audrey? Want me to make you something? Audrey pauses, staring, not sure what to say. Turns away.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Just make your tiki statue.  55.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I don’t think Jawari appreciates my efforts. Besides, you’re much prettier than Jawari.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I don’t want anything from you.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Oh, Audrey, that’s cold. That hurt my feelings.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I doubt you have any feelings.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: That's not true. I’m a sensitive guy. Really. He’s met with cold silence.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something. If I was just some guy you met. And you didn’t know anything about me. Would you even talk to me? She turns her face toward him, still not answering.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I just walked up to you somewhere and you didn’t know me. If we talked, just about simple things. And I didn’t do anything to creep you out. What would you think of me? Audrey vacillates, uncertain, then softly answers.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You might fool me. Rainy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I fool myself sometimes. Audrey raises her chin, strong with a bit of defiance.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: But I do know you. The smile fades from Rainy’s face.  56. AUDREY (CONT’D) I know all I need to know. You’re evil. You’re cruel and vicious. You’re a monster. And I wouldn’t want to talk to you. I wouldn’t want to see you. I wouldn’t want to have anything to do with you. Rainy scowls, speechless for once. Jawari laughs. Rainy glances angrily at him. Jawari keeps laughing as he pulls bag and rolling papers from his jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: You struck the fuck out, man.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Hey, fuck you, Zulu. Jawari just laughs more. Starts rolling a joint. Rainy fi to compose himself. When he calms down enough, it’s like another personality washes over him. He chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s pretty good, Audrey. You really got me. That’s funny. He starts whittling again.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know what I’m gonna make you, Audrey? A little giraffe. You like giraffes, don’t you? Everyone likes giraffes. I don’t know anyone who doesn’t like giraffes.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I didn’t think there was anyone who didn't like trees. Rainy pauses.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I was in the woods for weeks. All those trees became like prison bars. Who’s ever had an experience like that with giraffes? (to Audrey) Do you like giraffes, Audrey?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I don’t have anything else to say to you. Jawari laughs as he puts his joint in his mouth.  57.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Oooh, she shuts him down completely.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Hey, let me have a hit off that. Jawari digs out a lighter.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Nope. You stay over there. Rainy eyes Jawari a moment. Smirks with a chuckle as he resumes whittling. He focuses on Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: What about you, shy one? Do you like giraffes? Cheyenne nods.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, a lot of people think giraffes are weak because they got those long necks. But did you know a giraffe could kick a lion’s head off? Jawari laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: A giraffe couldn’t kick a lion's head off. Not with those bony legs.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: They're bigger than you think.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: They're not that big.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Their legs can get taller than a man. Their hindquarters can get bigger around than my waist. Jawari keeps laughing as he blows smoke.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Bullshit. Rainy shakes his head.  58.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you're going to smoke that all by yourself.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Hey, man, you ever heard of paying for it?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I paid for the beer.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I didn’t drink any beer.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: How much you want for a joint? Rainy pulls out his (Notta’s) wallet. Slips out two dolla

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’‘1l give you two bucks.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Two bucks?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: How much you want? Jawari starts rolling a joint.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I’1l take two bucks and you calm the hell down, how’s that sound? Rainy grins. Sets his sights on David.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: So what church do you belong to? I know you’re not Mormon. They travel in pairs. He glances at Jawari. They both laugh. David speaks softl

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Church of the Living Word.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: What is that, Jehovah’s Witnesses?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It’s protestant.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 59.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: What do they think about you being a homo? David looks up, stunned silent.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s what I thought. You know that’s a sin according to your bible, right? David forces a response.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m not gay.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Just like you didn’t see Audrey? David averts his eyes, caught out.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I bet you spent your whole life trying to get away from it. I bet you try and pray it away every day. David insists.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No... I don’t... I’m not...

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: It’s in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You can’t tell if someone's gay just by looking at them.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Yes, you can. He leans a little closer to David, provocatively.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They promised you inner peace, but you didn’t get shit, did you? Door to door in the hot sun for Jesus, and all you get in return is hi and bye on Sunday. Put your money in the plate and see you next week.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No. It’s more than that. +e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e HFK OF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 59A.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You ever feel the Holy Spirit in you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: A couple of times.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Ever speak in tongues? Allah ballah ballah... Jawari bursts out laughing. Tosses the joint to Rainy.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: There you go, man. Just mellow out. Rainy sticks the joint in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (re: his lighter) I want this back. Jawari tosses the lighter. Rainy catches it. Lights the j and takes a big draw. Blows smoke like all the tension is leaving his body with it.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Ah. This is some fine green, my friend. Not nary a crack or a pop of stem nor seed.  60. He tosses the lighter back. Jawari catches it.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: I told you my stuff doesn’t have a bunch of stems in it. Jawari pulls out a small bag of cocaine. Rainy perks up. Jawari spreads some of the powder onto the table top.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You need to borrow my knife? Jawari pulls a switchblade from his pocket. Pushes a butt forward... FLICK. A blade springs out. Jawari grins.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: No, thank you, cowboy. I got a real knife. He starts cutting up the coke.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: A balisong is better than a switchblade.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Come on, seriously? Think about it. My flick to your click-clack. See the difference? Two steps to one.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Fan knives are more reliable.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: You push a button, you got a knife. What could be more reliable? Besides, everybody knows switchblades are cooler than butterfly knives. There isn’t even a competition. Rainy starts carving on his log.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You can’t carve a giraffe with a switchblade. The blade’s too flimsy. Audrey interrupts...

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Do you have to do all this in front of my daughter?  61. Jawari pauses, almost as if he sees her point. Rainy blow smoke right toward Audrey and Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You can’t get high off secondhand pot smoke. If you could, we’d all be high off Jawari. BING. Jawari retracts the blade of his knife.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: It's just some coke. I’1l keep it away from her.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I’1l tell you what, Audrey. I’11 put out the joint if you’1l tell me about yourself. Audrey looks at Rainy, reluctant to agree.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: What do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: What do you do for a living?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I’m a waitress. Now will you stop blowing smoke at us? Rainy takes a draw. Blows smoke at Audrey.
