dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: After you answer some questions.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: How many questions?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t know. Let’s say, five.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I’ve already answered one.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Okay, then. Four more. Were you ever a cheerleader? Audrey is caught off guard.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: What does that have to do with anything?  62.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I’m asking the questions.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Were you popular in high school?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: That's completely subjective. Rainy wags his finger at her as he leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: No. No, see, it’s not. Whether or not you were popular in high school will tell me virtually everything about you.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: How is that?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Because high school is where people are shaped for the rest of their lives. What you were then versus what you are now tells me everything. Audrey muses over those words a moment.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t know whether I would be considered popular or not.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Yes, you do. People know whether or not they were popular in high school. Audrey pauses, hesitant to answer.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I was valedictorian. Rainy leans back excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I knew there was something about you. And now you’re a waitress. See, that tells me a lot. Did you go to college?  63. Audrey answers with an air of sadness.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I went for a couple of years but had to drop out. Rainy puts the joint out. It’s nearly finished now anyway

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Look how much we’ve learned in just four questions. You were valedictorian. You dropped out of college and became a waitress. Rainy leans forward with a telling smirk.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And don't think I didn’t notice the wording. You “had to” drop out. Not “I dropped out.” But “had to.”

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: It doesn’t mean anything. Lots of people drop out of college.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Not lots of valedictorians.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: It had more to do with money than anything else.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: A valedictorian who can’t get a scholarship?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Is that your final question?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: No. My final question is... He ponders. His eyes rest on... Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My final question is, did you drop out because you were pregnant? Audrey gazes at him, stunned speechless. She looks at Cheyenne. Cheyenne looks up at her mother.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Cheyenne is the best thing that ever happened to me.  64. Rainy sighs, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: That’s what every parent says. That’s such a generic load of bullshit. He leans toward Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something, shy one. People lie like lies will magically turn to money. And no one lies more than parents.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Sounds like someone had a bad childhood. Rainy smirks.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Kids come from fuckin’. So don’t act like you did somethin’ noble.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Do you have to talk that way in front of Cheyenne? Rainy shifts his focus back to Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Parents have babies for two reasons. They can’t control themselves sexually and babies are cute. Rainy’s aggression unsettles Cheyenne. Her eyes well up.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But babies grow up. And as they do, the shine wears off. Then parents start resenting the burden. That’s all parents.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Leave her alone. Cheyenne starts crying. AUDREY (CONT’D) That’s not true, Cheyenne.  65.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: It is true. All parents reach a point where they long for the freedom they once had. They secretly dream of all the things they might have achieved if they weren’t stuck. Audrey looks at Cheyenne, desperate to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: That’s not true. I’ve never once regretted having you.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: See, Audrey, you’re just like everyone else. Why can’t you just be honest?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You’ve had your last question. Now it’s my turn to answer. She looks down at a tearful Cheyenne. AUDREY (CONT’D) This is the truth, Cheyenne, I swear. Yes, I’ve had regrets in life. I’ve screwed up a lot of things. But I screwed them up. Not you. She looks up at Rainy. AUDREY (CONT’D) It's true. I got pregnant in college. I dropped out because I couldn't afford it. Nostalgia washes over her face. AUDREY (CONT’D) I didn’t know what I wanted to do with my life anyway. Motherhood seemed as good a purpose as any. Audrey's eyes meet with Cheyenne’s. AUDREY (CONT’D) It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done. It was tough and I barely scraped by. I thought so many times I’d never make it. But I swear, I never once regretted it.  66. Cheyenne faintly smiles. Rainy gauges Audrey, unconvinced

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: There’s something you’re not telling us. Cheyenne looks indignantly toward Rainy.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Why are you so mean? Jawari laughs as he pulls out a straw.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Yeah, cowboy, why don’t you tell us about your family? He snorts a line of coke off the table. Sniffs and tweaks nose.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I’‘1l1 tell you about my family if you'll give me a couple of lines. Jawari nods.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Okay. I gotta hear this.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Well, I wasn’t no high school valedictorian, I can tell you that. He and Jawari snicker.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My old man was a con artist.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Why am I not surprised?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: We travelled from place to place all the time. I was helping him run a shell game when I was only six. Jawari laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Little Rainy.  67.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I remember he broke into a used car lot office to steal keys one Sunday afternoon. And some people showed up thinking the lot was open. He sold ‘em a car.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: He sold ‘em a car? Rainy drifts off. Shakes his head in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: He filled out the paperwork and everything. He even pretended to call and check on their credit. He looks up at Jawari, still in awe after all these years

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The banks weren’t even open.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Damn, Rainy, your old man had a big set of balls on him.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I asked him why he did it and he just said, “I don’t know, I just wanted to see where it went.”

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Where was your mother? Rainy snaps out of his trance, looks at Audrey.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I never knew her. Jawari snorts another line. Raises his head, twitching.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: So you just ran around with your dad? That’s pretty cool. Rainy drifts off again. This time there’s something eerie about the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: When I was twelve, we broke into a house to rob the place. There was just supposed to be a woman alone. My dad made me wait in the living room. I could hear her begging.  68. Audrey swallows, nervous about where this is going. David Jawari both have the same look.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then I heard these noises. I didn’t really know what it was at the time. Then her husband came home. I ran to get my dad. When I opened the door, I saw him on top of her. He was so mad. Rainy sinks deeper into the memory.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He threw a pillow at me. Told me to get out. I guess the pillow hitting a lamp let her husband know we were there. He got a gun. Rainy’s eyes look as if he’s there, witnessing it all ove

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I climbed out the window first and hid in the bushes. I heard a shot. I saw my dad hit the ground. He just looked at me. His eyes were open but I could tell he was dead. Jawari gazes at Rainy, spellbound.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Wow. That’s fucked up, man.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I went to a state house. I’ve been a menace to society ever since. He chuckles. Stops laughing when David speaks.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: “Put up again thy sword into his place: for all they that take the sword shall perish with the sword.”

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Is that from the Bible?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Jesus said it. When they came to arrest him, one of his disciples cut off the ear of the high priest’s servant. Jesus put the ear back on and said those words.  69.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Jesus put someone’s ear back on? After it was cut off? Rainy glares, fighting to contain a dark fury.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Give me some Kool-Aid and a glass of water and I’1l show you how to turn water into wine.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Jesus’s miracles are documented.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: By who? His disciples? The same people who made a living off him? That's a little like Copperfield’s cable pullers claiming he can really fly, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: There were others. Jesus healed people.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Ever hear of the immune system?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The immune system can’t make the blind see.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Ever hear of a setup? You fake stuff for money.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: All those people wouldn't lie.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: ‘Cause people are known for their honesty, right? David pauses, musing. Looks away.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wanna see a magic trick? I bet I can make a line of coke disappear. (to Jawari) What do you say, bro? Look, I’11 put the rifle down. Rainy lays his rifle on the floor. Holds up the knife.  70.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’‘1l put the knife down. He sets it on the stove-top and shows his hand empty, fro and back. Holds up the log.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1l put the log down. He sets the log down NEXT TO THE KNIFE. Raises his hand t show it empty, PALM SIDE ONLY.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need something to help me relax after all this emotional outpouring. As he says this, we move behind him where we see... the k blade is clipped between his middle fingers, hidden from view. Jawari laughs, oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: JAWARI
dialogues.text: Okay, come on. You earned it. Rainy slowly approaches, hands still in the air.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Did I ever tell you why I was on the run from the police when I spent all those weeks in the woods? Jawari shakes his head, holds a straw out. Rainy reaches it with his empty hand. With his other hand, he... Flicks his wrist, slinging the knife into his hand.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Murder. He grabs Jawari’s hand as he stabs him in the gut. Jawari grunts, doubles over. The hostages stiffen, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I killed my ex girlfriend and her lover. I had to change my identity and everything. He lets go. Jawari slumps over, leaving Rainy with a bloo knife in one hand and the straw in the other. He snorts a line off the table. Shakes his head, twitching.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's what I’m talkin’ about.  71. Jawari shoves Rainy away. Grabs his switchblade and start push the button. Rainy puts his hand over it... BING. The spring releases but the blade doesn’t emerge.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See, the thing about switchblades, the blade has to lock. He stabs Jawari in the gut again. Jawari grunts. Rainy steps back. Jawari turns the knife handle upside do The blade limply slides out.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If something blocks it on the way out, it’s like a limp dick. I told you balisongs were better. Jawari carefully grabs the blade with index finger and th Pulls it out until it locks with a CLICK. He looks up at Rainy, face pale. Sweating. Quivering.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s a matter, Zulu? You look a little peaked. Jawari raises his blade. The two men square off for a kni fight. Rainy laughs playfully.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is one of those "what if" scenarios, like what happens when a shark meets a killer whale? He waves his knife.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m the killer whale and you’re the shark. Jawari takes a meager stab at Rainy and misses. Rainy sla Jawari’s arm. Jawari yells.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Looks like the killer whale is winning. Rainy stabs Jawari in the stomach. Twists the blade. Jawa eyes have a look of certain death.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s the same look my daddy had.  72. Jawari slumps to the floor by the table. Rainy kneels, wi the blood on the back of Jawari’s shirt. When he stands, he folds the knife and puts it away. Snor another line. He raises his head, sniffing and fidgeting. Audrey and th others watch, panicked. Rainy picks up the magazine.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Please don’t hurt us. Rainy steps toward the recliner.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: My giraffe’s not good enough for you, remember? He grabs the rifle. Inserts the magazine.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I’‘1l do anything you want. Just don’t hurt Cheyenne. David sits forward.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Look, there was no reason for this to escalate to murder. There still isn’t. He may still be alive. Rainy glances at Jawari. Slides a round in the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Thanks for pointing that out, David. BANG! He shoots Jawari in the back. The hostages avert th eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is just sell-out central around here today, isn’t it? First Audrey drags you into it. Then you try to weasel out of helping her. Now you want to make sure Jawari is dead.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean it like that.  73.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: What you mean is to keep yourself alive. Even at the expense of poor Audrey and Cheyenne here. He aims the rifle at David.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I‘1l tell you what I want you to do. I want you to pick someone. Whoever you pick gets killed and the other two can live. Which one’s it gonna be, David? David fights to keep composed. Sweat beads on his forehea

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I can’t make that choice.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Oh, but you must. You’re the one who goes around door to door asking everyone to make the most important decision of their lives right there on the spot.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You better. David's eyes dart around. His mind races for a way out. Finally, he relents.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No. I won’t choose.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: All right, then. I’11 make you choose. Rainy trains the barrel directly at Cheyenne’s face.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: No. Please. Don’t hurt my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Shoot me!  46 47 74.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Shut up! You’re too good for me! Then... David leaps from the couch and runs. Rainy aims. David reaches the threshold to the... LIVING ROOM —- DAY 46 BANG! A bullet rips through his knee. David groans as he tumbles to the floor. Rainy storms into the room.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You cowardly piece of shit! He pulls David up, leans him against the doorframe.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY ROOM/KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Rainy tromps to Cheyenne and aims at her face again. Tear stream down the little girl’s cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: (to David) I’m going to count down from ten to one. You're going to choose between yourself and Audrey. If you don’t make a choice by the time I get to one, then your choice is Cheyenne. Audrey bawls helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Please don’t hurt my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Shut up! You don’t get a choice. The choice is David’s. Are you ready, David?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Please... David tries to move his leg. Yells in pain.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Here we go. Audrey begs while Rainy counts. We cut back and forth bet the faces of all of them.  75.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ten... nine... eight... Please! No! I’m begging seven... six... five. you. I’11 do anything. No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: four... three... two... Shoot me! Shoot me! David softly murmurs...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Shoot me. Rainy pauses. Turns to David, lowering his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Shoot me. Rainy approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I’m impressed. You finally grew some balls. He raises the rifle to David’s face.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1l give you one last chance to change your mind. David looks at Audrey, his face quivering.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. He’s right. I’ve been a coward. I was afraid. I’ve been afraid my whole life. Always running away. He looks up at Rainy, courage filling his face.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not afraid anymore. Rainy braces the stock against his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Look at the bright side. You won’t have to go door to door no more. Audrey's voice cuts across the room.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I was raped.  76. Everyone turns toward Audrey. The room seems to freeze th way for a moment. Audrey fights back a flood of emotions. AUDREY (CONT’D) In college. At a frat party. I was smart enough to get a scholarship and dumb enough to think this guy cared about me. Her eyes turn glassy. Like she can see it all again. AUDREY (CONT’D) I wanted to impress him. I was nervous and I drank too much. The music was so loud. There were so many people. It was hot and stuffy. I got nauseous, so I asked him where the bathroom was. I remember tripping on the stairs. He caught me and we laughed at how tipsy I was. I trusted him. (getting more immersed) When he pushed me on the bed, I didn’t even know where I was at first. The room was spinning. When I told him to stop, he said it was my idea. I remember his weight. The pressure. I couldn’t move. I could barely breathe. I felt like I was in a coffin. But he wouldn’t stop. She pops back to the present, glances around. AUDREY (CONT’D) I turned him in to the president. It was his word against mine and he said it was consensual. When I wouldn’t let it go, I was expelled. She pauses, staring into empty space. AUDREY (CONT’D) I just left. I just gave up. I thought my life was over. Tears well in Audrey’s eyes as they fix on Cheyenne. AUDREY (CONT’D) And then the day came when I saw her. They put her in my arms and it was like... she was magical or something. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She was so small and frail and she needed me to take care of her. She looks up at Rainy, teary-eyed. AUDREY (CONT’D) So I carried on. The days went by and things got a little easier. Then one day I realized... she saved my life. Audrey turns sadly to Cheyenne. This is the big one. It’s scary but it’s time to confess the whole story. AUDREY (CONT’D) Thomas, the man you know as your father, was my first husband. The truth is, the reason he doesn’t pay child support is because he doesn’t have to. After we divorced, he asked if he could still see you and I said yes. He helped us for a while but after he remarried, he... he quit. Finally, the floodgates give way and Audrey breaks down. AUDREY (CONT’D) He’s a good man. And I am so sorry I lied to you. Your real father doesn’t want anything to do with you. I was too scared to tell you the truth. Because I’m a coward. Cheyenne’s eyes reach out with the kind of forgiveness on child can offer so quickly.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: You’re not a coward, Mom. I forgive you. Rainy sneers. He’s had enough.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Well, didn’t this all just turn into family time. But it doesn’t change a thing. David has already agreed to go the Jesus route.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: No one agreed to anything!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Audrey?  48 49 78. She looks at David. He’s filled with a calmness.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s okay. Cheyenne manages to get her hands free. She looks toward. the gun, sitting on the table. Rainy raises the barrel toward David, braces the stock against his shoulder once again.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Yeah, see? He wants to do it. Then... Cheyenne jumps from the couch, grabs the gun. It’ big comparatively, she can hardly hold it up. Audrey’s ey widen in horror. Rainy grins.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you even know how to use that thing, shy one? BANG! Cheyenne wildly fires toward the ceiling, the kick knocking her down. Pieces of ceiling fall on Rainy.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: shit! While Rainy is distracted, Audrey leaps from the couch an rushes at him, screaming. Shoulders him with all her migh They both trip over David’s legs and... LIVING ROOM —- DAY 48 They slam onto the floor. The rifle slides near a buffet table. Rainy grabs Audrey and pulls her down. She kicks h repeatedly. The kicks are ineffective and Rainy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Oh, darlin’, stop it. You’re turnin’ me on.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY ROOM/KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Cheyenne climbs to her feet, lugging the gun. David waves over with a nod. She hurries to him. He holds out his bin Cheyenne furiously tugs at them.  50 51 Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 79. LIVING ROOM —- DAY 50 Rainy climbs on top of Audrey, still laughing. Audrey is fighting so hard, it’s about all he can handle.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I love a woman who can wrestle. This goes on until... David raises the gun barrel to Rain temple, ropes still hanging off his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Get off her. Everything stops. Rainy stares at David. It’s quiet for several moments. Then... From outside, TIRES CRUNCH ACROSS GRAVEL. A car stops in back. A CAR DOOR OPENS. CLOSES. Everyone stays still and quiet. After a few moments, we h the BACK DOOR OPEN. FOOTSTEPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby enters carrying a satchel. The first thing he notic is Cheyenne. He looks at her, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you?

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Cheyenne. Bobby notices David sitting in the doorway to the living with his leg bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: David. Bobby sees Jawari lying dead on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on here? He steps so that he can see into the living room. He sees Rainy on top of Audrey on the floor. He sees that David i pointing a gun at Rainy.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 79A.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rainy?  80.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Uh... we had some issues.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What the goddamn hell is going on here? What happened to Jawari?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: We got into it and I accidentally killed him.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: That’s not true.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Shut up, Audrey! You don’t know what the hell you’re talking about!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Where’s the old man?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: He’s dead. Bobby angrily throws his hands in the air.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Goddamn it! I told you not to kill the old man!

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: He was already dead.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Well, where is he?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: He died four days ago.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: The will doesn’t get read ‘til next week. Bobby stares slack-jawed a moment. Glances at David.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Why is this asshole pointing a gun at you?

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: He got it while I was wrestling with Audrey. She’s probably gonna get the water rights next week.  81. Bobby reaches into his satchel.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Then she can go ahead and sign. He whips out his pistol, points it at David.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: First, you can put that gun down. David starts to set the gun down on the living room side.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: On the other side. Over here. David sets the gun down on the family room/kitchen side.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Slide it away. David shoves the gun. It slides to a stop a few feet away near the door.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Rainy) Get your gun. Rainy grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: It’s a rifle.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I don’t give a good goddamn if it’s Jawari'’s dick, pick it up. Rainy sighs, stays on his knees and leans across the floo grab the rifle.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Untie her. Rainy unties Audrey. Bobby puts his pistol back into his satchel and pulls out a contract. Rainy hands it to Audre Bobby holds out a pen.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sign it. Rainy hands Audrey the pen. She doesn’t even try to read contract, she just signs it. Rainy hands the items back t Bobby. He stuffs them into his satchel. Lowers the satche David, who eyes it intently.  82.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, what you may not realize is that wills are retroactive. It doesn’t matter when it’s read. The date of ownership of bequeathed items legally begins the moment the decedent dies. Bobby looks at Rainy with eyes of cold stone.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m going to leave now so you can clean up.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: We were promised we'd be let go! He scans between the two rooms, glancing at Jawari.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I wanted things to stay simple but as you’ve seen, Rainy is somewhat of a loose cannon. I think it’s best at this point to just clean up and go home. Then... David grabs Bobby’s satchel, pulls him into the living room. Bobby trips over David’s legs, falls on top Rainy.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Run! Audrey climbs to her feet and jumps over David, grabbing Cheyenne and pulling her along. As Audrey opens the door, Cheyenne snatches the gun off the floor. Rainy gets to his feet, rifle in hand.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Go get them. I’11 watch him. Rainy jumps over David. As he does, David grabs his ankle trips him. Rainy hits the floor, scrambles to his feet. H starts to kick David.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go on. I’1l take care of him. Bobby kicks David in his injured knee. David screams in agony. Rainy scuttles out the door.  52 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rainy bursts out the door in time to see Audrey and Cheye running away. He aims his rifle. Audrey and Cheyenne barely make it behind the tree that R peed on earlier before... BANG! A bullet smacks a patch o bark off the trunk. Rainy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Fuckin’ tree! BANG, BANG, BANG, BANG! He fires round after round as he closes in.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE TREE
dialogues.text: Audrey, back to the trunk, holds Cheyenne tightly to her while bullets riddle the tree. BANG, BANG, BANG! Pieces o bark explode on both sides. Then... silence. Audrey listens. Starts to peek when... Rainy’s face pops up.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boo! Audrey flinches, screams, quickly tucks Cheyenne behind h

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m gonna miss you, Audrey. This is the most excitement I’ve had since my daddy tried to drown me.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND AUDREY
dialogues.text: While Rainy talks, Cheyenne slips the handle of the gun i Audrey’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, that and killin’ my ex girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: And her lover. Rainy grins.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: And her lover. He raises the rifle, calls to the house.  84.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got ‘em! While he’s distracted, Audrey whips the gun around and po it at him. Rainy does a double-take.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I’ve got a gun too.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Audrey, Audrey, Audrey. I’m disappointed in you. This is a rifle.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. You have a rifle. And I have a gun.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Thank you. But what you don’t have... is the balls. He starts to make a move. It’s cut short... BANG! A bullet streaks by Rainy’s ear, leaving a trail of blood across the side of his head. Audrey screams, taken guard by the recoil. Rainy yells as he’s thrown back. He the ground with a thud.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Come on! She starts to run. Cheyenne grabs the barrel of Rainy’s rifle, jerks her hand back when it burns.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: It’s hot. Audrey grabs her.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Let’s go! They head for the barn. Rainy grabs the side of his head.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Audrey, you bitch! Rainy stumbles to his feet. Starts for the barn. Notices tree. Angrily kicks it.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuckin’ tree.  53 54 55 85. He turns and staggers toward the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door creaks open. Rainy peeks in cautiously. Steps in just as cautiously, scanning the area.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I’m impressed, Audrey. I misjudged you. That doesn’t happen often. He steps further in, looking around, assessing. There's a loft above on one side, long abandoned livestock stalls o the other. A door out the back.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I forgot I was dealing with a high school valedictorian. He snickers to himself.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got guts, Audrey. And you’re smart. And that’s a dangerous combination. He turns, certain she’ll give herself away.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know you’re in here. EXT. BARN’S BACK DOOR - DAY 54 Audrey waits by the side of the door with a shovel in her hands. Breathing heavily, trying to keep as quiet as she The gun is tucked into her pants.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You could have killed me. But you couldn’t bring yourself to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rainy nears the back door. He trains his rifle on the lof

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: You don’t have the kind of guts it takes to kill a man. It’s the eyes. Something about the eyes.  56 57 58 86. BANG! He fires a round into the loft. It blasts a chunk o the old wood into dust, tearing a hole through the floor. EXT. BARN’S BACK DOOR - DAY 56 Audrey flinches at the sound.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I sure hope shy one wasn’t in that loft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANG! BANG! BANG! Several holes are blasted into the loft Rainy turns toward the back door.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Where did you go, Audrey? Did you go off into the woods? He starts to step through the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's scary out in the woods -- Suddenly, the back of a shovel flies right toward his fac PING! It smacks him square in the nose, knocking his head back. He falters, hits the dirt. Audrey screams, charging with the shovel over her head. She levels it like an axe splitting wood. Rainy puts his arms up to shield himself. CRACK! Right across his forearm. Rainy yells. He tries to his rifle while Audrey draws back again. Just as he aims. Audrey screams, swings like a baseball bat. WHACK! Knocks the rifle out of his hand and into a stall. Rainy manages to grab the shovel’s handle near the scoop. Audrey tries to pull it back. Rainy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m gonna bury you with this shovel. Audrey abandons the shovel, runs out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey runs for her life. Approaches a bush.  59 60 61 87.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Cheyenne! Cheyenne peeks out from behind the bush. Audrey grabs her hand as she goes by.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s go! The two of them head for the woods. EXT. BARN’S BACK DOOR - MOMENTS LATER 59 Rainy totters out the door with his rifle. He sniffles fr his possibly broken nose and grunts from his busted forea Not to mention the blood across his temple from the bulle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rainy staggers into the open, near the woodpile. Bobby ha out a window in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What’s going on out there? Rainy calls out to him.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: I think I’m in love!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Quit fuckin’ around! Rainy regains some composure, stomps off toward the woods

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m done playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey and Cheyenne pause to listen.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The next two shots you hear are gonna be the last!

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: He’s coming after us. Let’s go. They turn and continue on, deeper into the woods.  62 63 64 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby pulls back into the house.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I’m tired of all this messing around. He sits on the buffet. David sits in the doorway. Sweat b on his face and his breathing has become erratic.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you're going to kill a mother and her little girl.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you’re next, if that helps you forget. He chuckles. David turns away. Notices something.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY ROOM/KITCHEN
dialogues.text: By Jawari’s body. The switchblade. LIVING ROOM —- DAY 64 David looks back at Bobby. Bobby pulls out a cell phone. Glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I wonder if I still have time to file today with the Water Resources Department. He pauses, looking at David.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The kid was probably just going to be another nobody anyway. Bobby starts dialing. David looks at the switchblade agai Can he sneak to it before Bobby notices?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (phone) Yeah, how late are you open? He climbs off the buffet, leaving his satchel behind.  65 66 67 89.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How long does it take to process a transferral of water rights? He turns his back absentmindedly. David sees his chance.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY ROOM/KITCHEN
dialogues.text: David crawls across the floor toward Jawari.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh really? So there’s really no way I could make it today. David grits his teeth, fighting the pain. Trying to do th as stealthily as he can.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So if I get there first thing tomorrow morning, I could have the rights in my company name before the day is out? David is almost there. Then he notices... eerie silence. pauses. Looks back at the doorway. Nothing. What is Bobby doing? David waits. Waits. Then...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That’s great. I can be there by nine. Can I get your name? The conversation is winding up. David hurries.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Bobby turns around as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Karen. I’1ll see you -- He stops cold when he sees the empty doorway.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. Bye. He shuts the phone off, eyes blazing. Rushes to the doorw

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY ROOM / KITCHEN
dialogues.text: David is at the front door, reaching for the knob.  68 90.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Trying to escape? What’s the matter with you? Bobby kicks him. David grunts, slides down onto the floor

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you thought you could crawl away. Bobby kicks him again. David groans, doubling over.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I should have shot you right from the get-go. He grabs David. Turns him over to pull him up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Go to hell. David stabs Bobby in the leg with the switchblade. Bobby screams as he falls back onto the floor with the knife st stuck in his leg.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You son of a bitch! David crawls toward the doorway to the living room. It ta all his strength but he desperately forces himself. Bobby grabs the knife handle. Screams as he pulls the bla out. Struggles to climb to his feet. David passes the threshold. Bobby lurches after.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should have slashed my throat.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: David reaches the middle of the floor when Bobby limps in with the switchblade.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You made the same mistake I did. David climbs up the buffet. Reaches for the satchel. Just he touches it... Bobby stabs him right in the back. David cries out. Falls back to the floor. The satchel drops beside him. Some pap slip out. The pistol slides out on top of them.  69 91. Bobby draws back and stabs David in the back again. And again. And again. Until... KINK! The blade breaks off. Bobby sees the broken metal, angrily tosses the handle away. He grabs the pistol. Uses buffet to pull himself to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I bet you wish you'd killed me from the start now, don’t you? David strains to turn himself over. Looks up at Bobby, quivering. He’s about to die and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don’t have any more regrets. He relents and succumbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey and Cheyenne hike through overgrowth. Climb down i a large shallow pit, grown over with grass. In the middle Audrey stops. Looks around, confused.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Cheyenne stops. Watches her mother. AUDREY (CONT’D) I remember this. This is the reservoir. Or it was. She glances around again, double-checking. AUDREY (CONT’D) The reservoir was right here. I’m sure of it.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: What happened to it?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. She scans ahead. Points. AUDREY (CONT’D) If I remember right, the creek must be right over there somewhere.  70 71 72 73 92.

dialogues.speaker: IN ANOTHER AREA 70
dialogues.text: Rainy trudges along, searching. He pauses, noticing something. A leaf about the level of his head. He steps closer. Takes the leaf into his hand and sees... blood. He feels his temple. The blood is his own. He smac the leaf aside in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Fucking circles! He looks down a pathway. The depth of field contracts. Th trees appear to close in. Rainy shakes it off. Looks anot direction. The trees close in that direction too. He looks another direction. Same thing. Then another. Onc again, the trees are closing in. He calls out.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Audrey!

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY 71
dialogues.text: Whirls, hearing him. She turns to Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: He’s gotten farther away. He must be going the wrong way. Let’s go. They head into a long stretch of woods, angled downward.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY 72
dialogues.text: Runs through the forest like a madman. He trips over a ro sticking out. Smacks the ground. He raises his face, then pauses, hearing something. The gentle WHOOSH of water.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: The creek. He climbs to his feet, moves its direction.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY 73
dialogues.text: Reaches the edge of the creek, followed by Cheyenne. They about twenty feet up and it’s a steep drop on both sides.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Should we go downstream? Maybe the water isn’t as deep.  74 75 76 93. Audrey studies the drop, covered with thick exposed roots

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: No. I think the roots will hold. She climbs down, stepping on roots like crooked ladder ru Audrey pauses when she’s completely over the side. AUDREY (CONT’D) Okay, Cheyenne. Be very careful. I’'ll be right below you. Cheyenne balks, extremely nervous.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: I’m scared.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I know you are, sweetie, but we'll be down before you know it.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY 74
dialogues.text: Forces his way through small branches. Emerges at a large creek bed. Smiles. It’s much lower than where Audrey and Cheyenne are but th bed covers a larger area. Rainy’s footsteps sink in the s bed as he approaches the creek. Rainy drops to his knees at the bank. The creek flows peacefully. Rainy splashes water on his face, upsetting t tranquility.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY 75
dialogues.text: Keeps one hand free to catch Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Make sure you have your footing before you take your next step. Cheyenne reluctantly places her foot on a root. It slips She screams.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY 76
dialogues.text: Raises his face, looking upstream. Grins. Grabs his rifle Splashes across the creek to the other side.  77 78 79

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY 77
dialogues.text: Clutches Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: It’s okay. I’ve got you. Cheyenne holds onto her mother, paralyzed with fear. AUDREY (CONT’D) Climb onto my back. Cheyenne hesitates. Tries to pull herself together. AUDREY (CONT’D) Come on, Cheyenne. We don’t have time. You can do it. Cheyenne shakily climbs onto Audrey's back. Audrey naviga the roots, struggling with the additional weight. They finally reach the very narrow creek bed. The creek, the other hand, is wide and the water is rushing. Audrey sets Cheyenne down. Surmises.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Are we going to cross it?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I don’t think we have a choice. Audrey climbs down into the water. It’s nearly waist deep AUDREY (CONT’D) Climb on. Cheyenne climbs onto Audrey’s back and Audrey wades acros

dialogues.speaker: RAINY 78
dialogues.text: Follows the creek on the other side. The whoosh of water faster now. He treks uphill.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY 79
dialogues.text: Is right at the bank. One more step and she’1ll be there. loses her footing and falls forward. Cheyenne catches the edge of the bank while Audrey goes under.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Mom!  95. Cheyenne’s face fills with panic. She pulls herself onto narrow bank.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom! Audrey breaks the surface, gasping. Reaching for the bank

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom! Cheyenne looks back and sees a root. She grabs it with on hand. Reaches for Audrey’s hand with the other. Smack! Their hands clasp. Cheyenne pulls with all her mig Audrey claws at the bank. With Cheyenne’s help, Audrey Manages to pull herself to the bank. She climbs out of the water. Rests on the bank. Struggles catch her breath. CHEYENNE (CONT’D) What happened?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: An undercurrent caught my foot. Cheyenne looks at her mother, shaken by the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Audrey nods, still catching her breath.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: All we got is each other. Audrey smiles with tears of pride welling in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: That’s plenty. Let’s go. They pull themselves to their feet. There’s another “root ladder” going up the other side.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: I think I can do it myself this time.  80 96.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You sure? (off her nod) Okay, then, go on. I'll be right behind you. Cheyenne starts climbing up the roots.

dialogues.speaker: BANK/WOODS
dialogues.text: Just as Cheyenne is about to reach the top... A rifle lowers into her face. Her eyes widen. Audrey, realizing Cheyenne has stopped, looks up to see... Rainy.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: What do we have here? This is a regular reunion. Speaking of, you must have had your first high school reunion by now.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I didn't go. Rainy shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Well, that’s a shame. And you were valedictorian. I would have thought you would have felt obligated to attend.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I couldn’t get the night off.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Waitress duty called, eh?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I would appreciate it if you would stop pointing that gun in my daughter’s face. Rainy smirks.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Audrey, how many times do I have to tell you? It’s a goddamn rifle. He braces the stock against his shoulder. Desperate, Audr looks toward Cheyenne.  97.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Cheyenne? It’s not hot right now. Cheyenne’s eyes move to the rifle barrel. Rainy smiles playfully, oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: Yes, it is rather nice out here by the creek, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: (to Cheyenne) Push it up.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: When? Rainy gets suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: What are you two talking about?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Now! Cheyenne grabs the rifle barrel, shoves it upward. From behind, Audrey reaches over and points her gun at Rainy. eyes widen. AUDREY (CONT’D) This is your last warning shot, motherfucker. BANG! Rainy grunts. Looks down. A bloodstain on his shirt over his chest grows with the pump of his heart. He looks Audrey in disbelief. Cheyenne pulls the rifle from his limp hand. It clangs do the drop and splashes into the creek. Rainy stands. Looks at his own blood on his trembling han Struggles to speak.

dialogues.speaker: RAINY
dialogues.text: If it... hadn’t been... for that... fuckin’ tree. He falls over the edge. Tumbles down the drop and splashe into the water. Cheyenne and Audrey climb up into the woods by the drop. Audrey gazes down, stunned by her own actions. After a fe moments, she realizes something.  81 82 83 98.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Okay, step back. She motions for Cheyenne to clear some room.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? Audrey raises the barrel into the air.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: There needs to be two shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby finishes pulling David's body next to Jawari’s. In distance, there’s a MUFFLED BANG. Bobby looks up.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: There went the other one. He limps into the...

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: He puts his papers back into his satchel. Puts his gun ba in. Takes the phone and dials. INT. BOBBY’S GRANDFATHER'S BEDROOM - DAY 83 RING. Bobby's grandfather grumbles in his sleep, half awakened by the ringing phone. It keeps RINGING until the man finally answers it.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY AND HIS GRANDFATHER ON THE PHONE
dialogues.text: Bobby turns excitedly, hearing his grandfather’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It’s Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I was sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I know but this is important.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Well, it damn well better be.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I got ‘em, Grandpa. I got the water rights. Grandfather recoils in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: You're jerking my chain.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No. I really got ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I don’t believe a word of it.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It’s true. I swear. The old man died.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Died? When did that happen?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Four days ago.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Four days ago! I can’t keep up with it anymore. I wish I'd known. I would have gone to the funeral. Or sent flowers or something. Bobby can’t wipe the smile off his face.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I got his granddaughter to sign. Grandfather's face goes blank.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: You muscled his granddaughter? Which one?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Who cares? Grandfather asks more sternly this time.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Which one?  100.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Audrey. Grandfather thinks back. Nostalgia fills his face.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Yes, Audrey. I remember little Audrey. I haven’t seen her in years. What’s she doing now?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Who cares? We got the water rights.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: You didn’t hurt Audrey, did you? Bobby hesitates, just now realizing he may have screwed u

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No. Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I'd be very upset if anything happened to Audrey.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: She’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I always liked her. If I remember right, she was the one who always liked to rub my whiskers.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Fuck Audrey, okay? She’s fine. Grandfather's face takes on a chilling tone.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Don’t talk to me that way. Bobby turns immediately submissive.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I’1l smack your nose around to the other side of your head.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, okay? I didn’t mean it. Audrey's fine, okay? I’m just tryin’ to tell you something.  101. The DOOR OPENS from the next room. Bobby glances that way

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can get the rights transferred tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Listen, Bobby. You’re next in line. If you screwed this up, it’s over for you.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I didn’t screw it up. It’s fine. Bobby calls out to the next room.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rainy, hurry up. I gotta get going. You need to clean up before it gets dark. Audrey appears out of the shadows, aiming the gun. Bobby freezes, shocked to see her. Audrey steps into the room.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Hang up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: What’s going on, Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Nothing. I’1l call you back.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Something's wrong, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No. Everything’s fine. I just gotta get off the phone. Grandfather lowers his head. He knows something’s wrong. last hope for a legacy has just vanished.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: You’re just like your father, Bobby. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby disconnects. Drops the phone in the satchel.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: No one told you to drop the phone in the satchel.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. You wanted the phone to call the police? Bobby starts to reach in. Audrey raises her gun higher.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Don’t. Bobby stops, frowns. He steps into the open as Audrey ste further in.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey, now, I didn’t kill anybody. All I wanted was for you to sign the papers. All I wanted was the water rights. I just told those guys to get the old man to sign. When they found out he was dead, they should have left. I didn’t know what they were gonna do. Audrey fixes the gun on Bobby. He stares down the barrel, visibly shaken. Audrey’s aim is steady. Her face is sure.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I want you to reach in slowly. If you want to live... take out the phone. If you want to die... take out the gun. Bobby vacillates. Then he reaches into the satchel so slo it seems like forever. He nervously clutches something. Audrey watches, wearing a poker face.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Well, I’ve already got the signature. So I guess there’s no sense in any more violence. He raises the satchel with his hand still in it... BANG! Blood spatters as a bullet rips through his chest. groans, wildly raising the satchel into the air.  85 103. BANG! He fires a round, blowing out the side of the satch and into the ceiling. Pieces of ceiling rain down on him. We follow him as he falls back in SLOW MOTION, his face filled with disbelief. All the way until he hits the floo with a RESOUNDING THUMP. Dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey ambles out the back door with the gun slack in her hand. Scans the barn and woodpile area as she approaches.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Cheyenne!

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE BARN
dialogues.text: Cheyenne peeks out from the bush she hid behind earlier.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Approaches the woodpile. AUDREY (CONT’D) Cheyenne! It’s okay!

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Here I am! Cheyenne comes running. Audrey looks at her like it’s the most amazing thing she’s ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Cheyenne. They run into each other’s arms. Hug tightly, trying to absorb the moment for all it’s worth. AUDREY (CONT’D) I love you.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: I love you too. They pull back with bittersweet faces.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: We don’t have to live on the farm. Exhausted smiles are as close to giggles as they can mana They slip back into a hug, propping each other up.  86 INT. MR. 104. PENDLETON’S OFFICE - DAY 86 SUPER: “One Week Later.” Mr. Pendleton sits at his desk and reads from a file. He closes

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: And so this concludes his last will and testament. The house is officially yours. the folder. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) I’m not sure if you'll want to live in it now or not, given all that’s happened. But it’s yours to do with as you please. Are there any questions? Audrey and Cheyenne, dressed nicely, sit across from him. Audrey is

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I didn’t hear you mention anything about the water rights.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: Water rights? Your grandfather got his water from the district. confused. This is news to her.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: But I thought Grandpa’s water was gravity fed from a creek. I remember playing around the reservoir when I was a kid.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: Yes, when you were a child, maybe. But he switched to district water over twenty years ago. He was too old to maintain the pipes.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Then who owns the water rights?

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: The state. The law is that if water rights aren’t exercised for five years or more, they go into forfeiture.  105.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Did Grandpa know this?

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: I don’t know. He would have been nearly eighty when it went into forfeiture. It’s entirely possible he couldn’t read or understand the notices.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I don’t think he did. So Grandpa couldn’t have sold the water rights even if he wanted to?

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: He could have gotten them from the state. Anyone could.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You mean those rights were up for grabs for anyone who wanted them?

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: Yes, anyone. Audrey stares, completely flabbergasted. She can’t proces it. Mr. Pendleton becomes concerned. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) Are you okay? She doesn’t answer. She just stares, distant. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) Audrey? Finally, Audrey breaks down. She buries her face in her h and cries. It upsets Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: MR. PENDLETON
dialogues.text: It'll be all right. You can sell off some of the trees to the sawmill. That should get you by.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: Don’'t cry, Mom. As Audrey's “crying” progresses, it becomes more and more evident that she’s not crying at all. She’s laughing.  106.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I’m not crying, sweetie. She raises her face. She’s on the verge of crying, but laughing nonetheless.

dialogues.speaker: CHEYENNE
dialogues.text: What’s so funny?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: All they had to do was ask. She keeps laughing and fighting back tears. AUDREY (CONT’D) All they had to do was ask. FADE OUT.
